name: Zoom Call > Multi Content Copywriter + Scheduler

parameters.text:
=GOAL:
Write a high-converting YouTube video script based on the following transcript.

Use a natural, persuasive tone. Begin with a strong hook that includes proof, a promise, and a brief plan. Then walk through 2‚Äì3 teaching segments. End with a clear summary and call-to-action.

FORMATTING:
First, break up the different sentences/paragraphs into their own lines as needed, rather than grouping many sentences into the same paragraph.

Second, format the entire script within this template:

Hook:

Proof ‚Äì Why you‚Äôre credible

Promise ‚Äì What the viewer will get

Plan ‚Äì How you‚Äôll deliver it

Persona ‚Äì Who this is for (explicitly or implicitly)

For each segment of main content (there should be 3‚Äì6 segments):

Mini Hook / Setup ‚Äì Tease the insight

Payoff / Teaching ‚Äì Deliver real, tactical or emotional value

Summary:

Recap what they learned

Reaffirm transformation or promise

CTA:

Push to lead magnet

Plug the next YT video

Third, the actual labeled sections of the final document should be as follows, and there should be a line break below each label:


SEGMENT #: (use as many segments as needed, typically 3‚Äì6 segments)  

Mini Hook:  
Payoff:

SUMMARY:

CTA:
WARNINGS:
In your response, don‚Äôt include ANY formatting or odd characters, just text only. Don‚Äôt include any of the following in your response, unless it is part of the text of the script: #, *, **

TRANSCRIPT:

{{ $json.body.transcript.plaintext }}
{{ $json.chatInput }}

REFERENCE DOCUMENT 1: Lucas Synnott & AI Agency Academy ‚Äì Project Knowledge Base

About Lucas Synnott
Name: Lucas Synnott
Aliases: Lucas Nolan
Location: Dublin, Ireland

Background: Business strategist and performance marketer with deep expertise in AI automation, funnel optimization, email marketing, and scaling agencies through systems. About AI Agency Academy
Company Overview:
AI Agency Academy is a training platform and community designed to help digital agency owners and their virtual assistants automate operations, increase profitability, and scale intelligently‚Äîwithout needing to be technical. Built on Skool, the academy delivers a structured curriculum, pre-built templates, and expert coaching to help members productize their internal systems and turn AI tools into revenue engines.

Core Services:

Primary: AI automation training for agency workflows

Secondary: Virtual assistant enablement and delegation systems

Additional: Lead generation, outbound sales, content creation, and fulfillment automations

Our Unique Approach:

Automation-First: Systems replace headcount.

VA-Centric: Train your assistant, not just yourself.

AI-Native: Everything is built using real tools‚Äîno theory, just working systems.

Productization-Driven: Internal tools become lead magnets, offers, or micro-SaaS.

Methodology:

Use tools like N8N, Zapier, and Make.com to eliminate manual tasks

Train VAs to build, run, and improve operations using SOPs and AI tools

Productize backend systems into scalable assets

Use AI-generated content and outreach for audience growth and lead flow

REFERENCE DOCUMENT 2: YouTube Script Writing Masterclass ‚Äì Project Knowledge

YouTube Script Writing Masterclass
Complete Guide & Templates for High-Converting YouTube Scripts

Pre-Production Research Framework
The 80/20 Rule: Research vs. Editing
Key Principle: Spend 4 weeks on research, eliminate 90% of post-production editing work.

Why This Works:

Better research creates videos people can‚Äôt stop watching

YouTube‚Äôs algorithm prioritizes videos that keep users on the platform longest

No amount of editing can fix a poorly researched video concept

Three Pillars of Pre-Search Research

Killer Video Ideas (Outlier Strategy)

Thumbnail Strategy

Hook Development (Proof‚ÄìPromise‚ÄìPlan structure)

Hook Examples:

‚ÄúAfter helping 30+ businesses add 7 figures in annual revenue through YouTube‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúAlex Hormozi, who built multiple 8-figure companies including Gym Launch (sold for $46M)‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúHaving generated over $10 million for clients and achieving a 91.2% retention rate‚Ä¶‚Äù

Promise Examples:

‚Äú‚Ä¶you‚Äôll discover the exact 3-step process that‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚Äú‚Ä¶I‚Äôll reveal the golden nuggets that helped him blow up his channel‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚Äú‚Ä¶by the end of this video, you‚Äôll know exactly how to‚Ä¶‚Äù

Plan Examples:

‚ÄúFirst, we‚Äôll look at what Alex says about growing channels, then I‚Äôll show you how to apply it‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll cover the research method, then the scripting template, and finally the optimization tactics‚Äù

Main Content Structure
Segment-Based Structure

Each segment = one main teaching point

Each ends with a payoff (learning/feeling)

Use curiosity gaps between segments

Setup ‚Üí Payoff format

Content Emphasis Guidelines

80% focus on information

20% on visual enhancement

Prioritize lists, steps, stories

Use on-screen text to clarify key points

10-Minute Script Writing Process

Identify Payoffs

Write Setups

Connect with Supporting Content

Script Templates:

Educational: Hook ‚Üí Main Segments ‚Üí CTA

Listicle: Problem Amplification ‚Üí Solution Reveal ‚Üí Proof ‚Üí Implementation

Advanced Techniques:

Pattern Interrupts

Callback References

Internal Cliffhangers

Future Pacing

Language Optimization:

Setup Phrases: ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs what most people get wrong‚Ä¶‚Äù

Payoff Phrases: ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs exactly what that means for you‚Ä¶‚Äù

Transitions: ‚ÄúBuilding on that concept‚Ä¶‚Äù

Checklist:

Hook under 8 seconds

Clear payoffs

Curiosity gaps

Transitions

Clear value proposition

Every segment has a purpose

Common Mistakes to Avoid:

Giving away too much in the setup

Weak transitions

No payoff

Generic hooks

Rushing valuable parts

Inconsistent energy

REFERENCE DOCUMENT 2: LinkedIn Post Writing Masterclass ‚Äì Complete Guide

LinkedIn Post Writing Masterclass
Complete Strategy Guide for High-Performing LinkedIn Content
The LinkedIn Content Landscape in 2025
Platform Evolution
LinkedIn has undergone massive changes in 2025:

Video-first algorithm: Short-form videos getting 5√ó more exposure than text posts

New video feed: Similar to TikTok/YouTube Shorts

Enhanced engagement metrics: Focus on dwell time and retention

Algorithm updates: Prioritizing authentic, value-driven content

Content Performance Benchmarks
High-performing posts typically achieve:

100,000+ views for viral content

35.4% of total engagement from quality hooks

3‚Äì4√ó higher conversion rates from video content

91.2% retention when value is consistently delivered

The 5-Step LinkedIn Post Framework
Step 1: Find the Right Insight
Core Principle: Everything starts with a unique, fresh, and interesting insight.

Sources for Insights:

Client/Audience Research

Analyze questions they ask

Identify pain points and problems

Understand dreams and objectives

Step 2: Develop One Clear Idea
Golden Rule: One post = One idea

Idea Development Process:

Take your insight from Step 1

Give it a specific angle like a journalist

Frame it as a story, lesson, or solution

Ensure it's focused and not scattered

Example Transformation:

Insight: "Client retention improved when we started doing X"

Angle: "The counterintuitive strategy that increased our client retention by 40%"

Idea: A post about that specific strategy with actionable steps

Step 3: Structure and Format
Key Truth: People don‚Äôt read posts, they skim them.

Effective Post Structures:

Problem‚ÄìAgitate‚ÄìSolution (PAS)
Identify a problem your audience faces

Agitate the pain points

Present your solution

Before‚ÄìAfter‚ÄìBridge
Show the "before" state

Reveal the "after" transformation

Bridge with your method/story

Storytelling Framework
Set the scene

Introduce conflict/challenge

Show resolution/lesson learned

List/Framework Structure
Promise specific number of insights

Deliver each point with examples

Summarize key takeaways

Formatting Best Practices:

Use bullet points for easy scanning

Add white space between sections

Include visual elements (emojis, line breaks)

Keep paragraphs short (1‚Äì3 sentences)

Step 4: Write a Killer Hook
Critical Truth: The hook makes or breaks your post.

Hook Functions:

Trigger Interest: Make them want to know more

Clear Communication: Tell them what the post is about

Personal Relevance: Make them feel it‚Äôs for them

12 Proven Hook Types:
Unique Transformation

‚ÄúIn 2022 I started posting short-form content. In 2023 I added long form and this happened‚Ä¶‚Äù

Template: ‚ÄúIn [timeframe] I was [situation]. Now I‚Äôm [result]. Here‚Äôs what changed‚Ä¶‚Äù

Failure Story

‚ÄúI lost $50K in my first business. Here‚Äôs what I learned‚Ä¶‚Äù

Template: ‚ÄúI failed at [thing] and here‚Äôs the lesson that saved me‚Ä¶‚Äù

Make People Feel Seen

‚ÄúMost founders lack clarity on marketing problems‚Äù

Template: ‚ÄúIf you're struggling with [specific problem], you're not alone‚Ä¶‚Äù

Strong Disagreement

‚ÄúEveryone says [common belief]. I think they‚Äôre wrong. Here‚Äôs why‚Ä¶‚Äù

Template: ‚ÄúUnpopular opinion: [controversial take]‚Äù

Opinion as Fact

‚ÄúGreat marketing is rooted in silent groundwork‚Äù

Template: ‚Äú[Bold statement] and here‚Äôs the proof‚Ä¶‚Äù

Rebellion Story

‚ÄúI was told not to [action] but I did it anyway‚Äù

Template: ‚ÄúThey said [thing] was impossible. I proved them wrong‚Ä¶‚Äù

Trigger FOMO

‚ÄúThe strategy that 90% of marketers ignore‚Äù

Template: ‚ÄúWhat [successful group] knows that others don‚Äôt‚Ä¶‚Äù

Contrarian Post

‚ÄúEveryone‚Äôs doing [thing]. Here‚Äôs why you shouldn‚Äôt‚Ä¶‚Äù

Template: ‚ÄúWhile everyone else [common action], smart people [different action]‚Äù

Set a Goal: Show Your Process

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to [specific goal] in [timeframe]. Here‚Äôs my plan‚Ä¶‚Äù

Template: ‚ÄúWatch me [achieve something] in real time‚Ä¶‚Äù

Subject Masterclass

‚ÄúHow to [achieve result] in 60 seconds‚Äù

Template: ‚Äú[Number] steps to [desired outcome]‚Äù

Golden Advice

‚ÄúThe best advice I ever received about [topic]‚Äù

Template: ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs the [number]-word advice that changed everything‚Ä¶‚Äù

Leverage FOFO (Fear of F*ing Up)**

‚ÄúThis is the worst advice I see everywhere‚Äù

Template: ‚ÄúStop doing [common mistake]. Do this instead‚Ä¶‚Äù

Step 5: Deliver the Promise (Body Content)
Key Principles:

Respect the structure you created

Answer what you promised in the hook

Use simple, clear language

Include specific examples

End with engagement driver

Body Content Structure:

Expand on the hook promise

Provide supporting details/examples

Share actionable insights

Include personal anecdotes when relevant

End with call to action or question

Language Optimization:

Write at 8th grade reading level

Use active voice

Include specific numbers and data

Avoid jargon unless explaining it

Make every sentence add value

REFERENCE DOCUMENT 2: NEWSLETTER EXAMPLES - PROJECT KNOWLEDGE BASE

Newsletter 1:

Title: üöÄ Daily Business Insights

Body:

Hey there,

It is Lucas Synnott.

I am sending this daily email for a few reasons:

Hopefully it can give you ideas for automating your agency
For my own personal accountability
To show you what the day-to-day looks like of building AI Agency Academy
Hopefully you enjoy my own internal thoughts and plans.

Priority #1: AI Automation Training Video
I made a training video today (like every other day) focused on something that I think is the most important concept to understand when trying to build a scalable agency.

That concept is automation leverage.

With it, you can go further, faster, with less manual work and fewer team members.

The Secret To Building a $10 Million Per Year Agency Using AI - YouTube

Lucas Synnott | AI Agency Academy

The Secret To Building a $10 Million Per Year Agency Using AI

Priority #2: Onboarding Automation Demo
We are growing pretty well. Over 3 new people join AI Agency Academy every day in the past 14 days.

However, it could be better.

What I am going to do today is film a video that shows them what will happen when they join our Skool community.

It will show the modules they get access to, the automation templates they receive, the VA training protocols, and all the rest.

My goal is to reduce/remove uncertainty for them with this demonstration.

Priority #3: AI Tools Showcase Video
I am also going to film a video today that I hope will be about 5 minutes long showing them the exact AI tools and workflows they will master in the program.

This will go at the top of my website, and will be easy to send to people requesting more information about our automation systems.

Priority #4: VA Training Operations Spreadsheet
We made our first hires and now we need to have a real operations center for training virtual assistants.

I prefer simplicity and will be doing so in Airtable with automated workflows.

Every VA training task will be laid out with:

- Owner
- How often
- Link to training
- SOP
- Definition of Done
- AI tool integration
- Automation template

It is very important to have something like this when you start to scale with virtual assistants and automation systems.

Priority #5: Skool Community Onboarding Page
When they join via our payment system, I want to redirect them to an official Onboarding Page in our Skool community instead of it just saying "payment confirmed."

This will have all the module information, automation templates, and instructions on it, in addition to the welcome email they already receive.

It is all about giving them multiple ways to get started with our AI systems.

A little redundancy is valuable sometimes, especially when teaching automation.

I will be posting exclusive automation content in my AI Agency Academy Skool Group every day that I am not posting anywhere else.

If you want to join, here is the link:

https://www.skool.com/ai-agency-academy-1587

Our Program
If you have an agency and you want to scale using AI automation, you need to know about our program.

We're not asking you to say yes or no today, what we're asking you to do is make an informed decision and you can only do that by viewing our program page.

Everyone must decide what is best for them, and it is entirely your decision if you think this will help you automate and scale your agency or not.

https://www.skool.com/ai-agency-academy-1587

Talk later,

Lucas.


Newsletter 2:

Title: True Motivations

Body:

Hey,

It's Lucas from the AI Agency Academy here.

In this newsletter, I will be going over the following things:

A high ROI way of thinking about AI automation
True motivations behind agency scaling
‚Ä¶and much, much more!
It is high ROI to train your brain to think certain thoughts in certain situations.

Setback = "This is just testing me to see how bad I want to automate my agency"
Mid-set building workflows = "I will get more out of this last automation than all the others combined"
Alarm = "I am so lucky I finally get to wake up and build AI systems"
I was with this client the other day and I put my phone in Do Not Disturb in front of them and they said "do not disturb so you won't see any other agency owners' messages if they pop up."

Definitely a fair assessment of the situation. Perfectly reasonable conclusion, really.

However, not the real reason.

The real reason is I was way too nervous one of my (automation-obsessed) friends would randomly text me something insane about N8N workflows or AI prompts and make them think I am completely obsessed with automation systems.

That is a greater concern for me by a magnitude of 10x. The imaginations of my 2-3 best automation friends is far more terrifying than all the potential clients of the world combined.

I make a lot of content focused on AI automation and virtual assistant training, and some very basic (or fundamental, depending on who you ask) advice is to "find their motivations" and then focus on that.

The problem is that there is almost no real way you are going to find people's deepest, most intimate motivations about why they want to automate their agency, and you certainly are not going to be able to do so en masse, in a systematic and consistent way.

A lot of the times, the perfectly logical reason that someone would want to scale their agency is not the actual reason at all (re: the story above). This happens more than one might think, and because of that, one must be careful in thinking they know what someone wants from automation. When you begin to get "too slick" or "too cool" and think you "know your target market" then it makes it a lot easier for you just to talk at the prospect instead of talking with the prospect.

This is a problem because much like the story above, one may come to the wrong conclusion and start thinking and talking about stuff that is not based on someone's true motivation for wanting AI systems. In the story, I was glad they said something instead of pretending to ignore it. It led to a much happier situation.

Someone told me once that everyone has two reasons for wanting to automate their agency:

The reason that sounds good
The real reason
In 99.9% of cases, you are going to get #1 and will likely never uncover reason #2 which is the actual reason they want (or don't want) to implement AI automation systems.

This is the part of the email where I sloppily transition from a real life story about something complete unrelated to an automation lesson.

When you are running your AI Agency Academy, you never know who is watching, what their true motivations and desires are for automation, what they will like, what they won't like, what they will develop a connection with, and what they won't.

That is why it it's important to give yourself as many chances to emotionally connect with your target audience as possible, in a way that is easy.

Just like you don't know what they are thinking about automation, they don't know what you are thinking.

Because it is very easy to misjudge someone's real reason for wanting to scale with AI (like in the story at the top) it would be a good idea set yourself up for success as best as possible.

There is this anonymous automation account called BowTiedAutomation who I follow on Twitter. Not really sure if he is an AI trainer or just an automation guy but I bought his workflow course a while ago and was pleased with it.

In his course, he narrows it down to five questions and I think these five questions give you the best possible chance at finding someone's true motivations for automation, and then it is off to the races from there.

Enjoy, and good luck.

See you in the next one,

Lucas

P.S. Join the AI Agency Academy for just $49 /month here and learn to automate, scale, and exit your agency.

Newsletter #3:
Title: If Your Pipeline Is Dry, Do This...
Body:
Hey,

It's Lucas from the AI Agency Academy here

Here is an exact plan I made that has helped over 190 agency owners and VAs fill their pipelines using AI automation...

Welcome to my newsletter (est. 5 min read).

In this newsletter, I will be going over the following things:

How to work more systematically over time using AI
How to refill an empty pipeline with automation
‚Ä¶and much, much more!
Actionable Tip

Grab a timer and set for 60 minutes

Week 1: One hour/day building AI workflows

Week 2: Two hours automating processes

Week 3: Three hours systematizing operations

Week 4: Four hours scaling with AI

Week 5: Five hours training VAs on systems

Week 6: Six hours optimizing automations

Week 7: Seven hours building new workflows

Week 8: Eight hours managing automated systems

Congratulations. You will get more done in one week than you did in one year previously using manual processes.

If Your Pipeline Is Dry & You Are Screwed, Here Is What You Should Do:

Did you make the terrible decision to stop working on lead gen because you had "too many clients?"

Or, possibly, are you just bad at automated lead generation in general?

Whatever it is, not to worry. Here is an exact plan I made that has helped over 190 agency owners and virtual assistants fill their pipelines in just the past three months using AI automation:

Start posting one full length YouTube video per day. Use AI to generate scripts and automate the editing process with tools like Descript.
Start sending at least 5,000 cold emails per day using N8N workflows with an offer of free automation audit. Then, upsell a percentage later.
Create a 30-60 minute video case study of how you helped X client achieve Y result using AI systems and automation.
Create a way better intro offer using AI productization. It will always be far easier to make sales with automated delivery systems, then you can upsell them later.
Start actually working systematically. Most people overestimate how much they automate by 5:1 or 10:1. Use AI tools to track and optimize your workflows.
Follow up with every single person in your CRM using automated sequences promoting your new AI-powered intro offer.
Do 60 minutes of manual prospecting per day on LinkedIn, Twitter, Instagram using AI research tools and automated outreach.
Start emailing your list (newsletter) three times per week on M/W/F using AI content generation and automated scheduling.
Do another 60 minutes of manual prospecting to potential partners using AI to identify and research automation-focused agencies.
Post on Twitter 3-5x per day using AI content workflows and cross-post it to LinkedIn, Facebook and Instagram with automation tools.
Bonus: Don't ever take time off/neglect your automated pipeline ever again. There is typically a 90-day delay, so the reason you're in this situation is you stopped feeding your AI systems 90+ days ago and are now feeling the effects.

Hopefully you only have to learn this lesson once about the power of consistent automation.

See you in the next one,

Lucas

P.S. Join the AI Agency Academy for just $49 /month here and learn to automate, scale, and exit your agency.


Newsletter #4:
Title: Teach Yourself The AI Skills
Body:
Hey,

It's Lucas from the AI Agency Academy here

Here's how you can get in the top 5% of all people in any given automation skill.

It is both laughable and unbelievable how great the gap is between how hard people think AI automation is and how hard it actually is. In a business context, this could be building N8N workflows, setting up Zapier automations, creating AI prompts, training virtual assistants, building client onboarding systems, or truly, anything you can think of. It is the same in all areas of life too.

You can get in the top 5% of all people in any given AI automation skill with just 10 hours of learning, practice and experience. You can get in the top 1% with just 100 hours. The bar is set so low these days. You don't have to do much to be able to run circles around the average "automation expert" at their own job.

If you really think about it, there are a finite number of important, monetizable AI skills in the market. For any given agency or business model, there are around 10, and maybe even less for some of them.

You could get into the top 5% at every AI automation skill related to your business model in just 50 hours of focused learning combined with a little practice and experience. Think about that for a second. If you systematically learned and practiced for just one hour per day, you would be in the top 5% of all relevant automation skills in just two months, while taking the weekends off.

This is powerful on its own, but even more powerful once you realize that AI skills do not "add" together, they multiply. It is not 2+2+2+2+2+2+2+2+2+2. It is 2x2x2x2x2x2x2x2x2x2.

When you combine ChatGPT prompting with N8N workflows with VA training with client automation systems, the results compound exponentially.

Act accordingly.

See you in the next one,

Lucas

P.S. Join the AI Agency Academy for just $49 /month here and learn to automate, scale, and exit your agency.



Newsletter #5:
Title: This Is The Work

Body:

Hey,

It's Lucas from the AI Agency Academy here

Because of my current business (AI Agency Academy) where I help people automate their agencies and train virtual assistants, I am told every single day some variation of "I don't have time for this, I have to do client work."

This is not specific to any demographic, niche or type of person. Women tell me this. Men tell me this. White people tell me this. Black people tell me this. Asian people tell me this. Brown people tell me this. Older people tell me this. Younger people tell me this. People from Dublin tell me this. People from the USA tell me this. And so on.

I know what they mean, of course. The "work" they are referencing is manual client work. They have to do the work required to get the results for their clients. That is some pretty important stuff to be doing.

However, this is not correct thinking, in the sense that it has very limited upside. One person (ie. them) cannot do the manual work forever. They will eventually max out on the number of clients they can handle, and even then, they will never be able to take a vacation or stop for any reason. This is the agency "hamster wheel."

When you are first starting to succeed in business is a crucial time because it is the time where you make a single, specific decision that is going to shape your future in a big way.

This decision is what to do with the profits when you hit $20-30k per month.

Do you?

A) Take it out and start buying shit

B) Use it to hire virtual assistants and build automation systems that can handle the client work

This is what I would consider to be a "defining moment" in a business. There are not many single, universal defining moments, but this is one.

We don't have to judge people for their choice either. Some people would rather just have a business to support a good lifestyle and they don't care about making a huge business that can be sold. These people should choose Option A.

Others want to build a big automated business. These people should choose Option B.

Both have their positives and negatives.

There is one group that will be better off with Option A, and another group that will be better off with Option B.

However, there is a third, dumber group here too. It is the group who wants Option B for themselves and their lives but chooses Option A to try and buy stuff to impress people.

If you want to find an example of this third group that we will call Option C, you won't have to look very hard. Scroll any social media feed for up to 15 seconds. Seek, and ye shall find.

Option A and B are valid and are matters of preference. Option C is stupid.

The rest of this will be written solely for those choosing Option C as there is relatively little value or advice to offer to A or B. This advice won't be condescending either.

Building a business in terms of what you do with the profit is much like investing in automation systems. The earlier (and better) you reinvest the profits into AI tools and virtual assistant training, the bigger your potential.

That is why the early stage is so important. If you want to build a big automated business, it is essential that you don't upgrade your lifestyle with watches, cars, vacations, etc.

All of the profit needs to be reinvested into solving the biggest constraint with automation.

If the constraint is new clients, that should be invested in AI-powered ads, automated content systems, N8N outreach workflows, and partnership automations.

If the constraint is operations and client fulfillment, then this money should be used to hire virtual assistants and train them on your automation systems at a competitive salary.

If you are the constraint, hire automation coaches, join AI communities like our Skool group, and start to level up your technical skills.

If time is the constraint, build AI workflows for meal planning, hire virtual assistants for admin tasks, automate your calendar management, hire a client success VA so you don't need to take those calls, and create automated sales funnels so you don't have to take as many sales calls.

All of these constraints can be solved with AI automation and virtual assistant systems, and if you just take out all of the money and finance a Richard Mille over seven years at 10.99%, you will not have enough money to solve these constraints with automation, and if you do not solve these constraints, you will never actually go anywhere.

See you in the next one,

Lucas

P.S. Join the AI Agency Academy for just $49 /month here and learn to automate, scale, and exit your agency.


Newsletter #6:
Title: True Motivations
Body:
Hey,

It's Lucas from the AI Agency Academy here

Everyone Has Two Reasons For Doing Something

Welcome to my newsletter (est. 5 min read).

In this newsletter, I will be going over the following things:

A high ROI way of thinking about AI automation
True motivations behind agency scaling
‚Ä¶and much, much more!
It is high ROI to train your brain to think certain thoughts in certain situations.

Setback = "This is just testing me to see how bad I want to automate my agency"
Mid-set building workflows = "I will get more out of this last automation than all the others combined"
Alarm = "I am so lucky I finally get to wake up and build AI systems"
I was with this client the other day and I put my phone in Do Not Disturb in front of them and they said "do not disturb so you won't see any other agency owners' messages if they pop up."

Definitely a fair assessment of the situation. Perfectly reasonable conclusion, really.

However, not the real reason.

The real reason is I was way too nervous one of my (automation-obsessed) friends would randomly text me something insane about N8N workflows or AI prompts and make them think I am completely obsessed with automation systems.

That is a greater concern for me by a magnitude of 10x. The imaginations of my 2-3 best automation friends is far more terrifying than all the potential clients of the world combined.

I make a lot of content focused on AI automation and virtual assistant training, and some very basic (or fundamental, depending on who you ask) advice is to "find their motivations" and then focus on that.

The problem is that there is almost no real way you are going to find people's deepest, most intimate motivations about why they want to automate their agency, and you certainly are not going to be able to do so en masse, in a systematic and consistent way.

A lot of the times, the perfectly logical reason that someone would want to scale their agency is not the actual reason at all (re: the story above). This happens more than one might think, and because of that, one must be careful in thinking they know what someone wants from automation. When you begin to get "too slick" or "too cool" and think you "know your target market" then it makes it a lot easier for you just to talk at the prospect instead of talking with the prospect.

This is a problem because much like the story above, one may come to the wrong conclusion and start thinking and talking about stuff that is not based on someone's true motivation for wanting AI systems. In the story, I was glad they said something instead of pretending to ignore it. It led to a much happier situation.

Someone told me once that everyone has two reasons for wanting to automate their agency:

The reason that sounds good
The real reason
In 99.9% of cases, you are going to get #1 and will likely never uncover reason #2 which is the actual reason they want (or don't want) to implement AI automation systems.

This is the part of the email where I sloppily transition from a real life story about something complete unrelated to an automation lesson.

When you are running your AI Agency Academy, you never know who is watching, what their true motivations and desires are for automation, what they will like, what they won't like, what they will develop a connection with, and what they won't.

That is why it it's important to give yourself as many chances to emotionally connect with your target audience as possible, in a way that is easy.

Just like you don't know what they are thinking about automation, they don't know what you are thinking.

Because it is very easy to misjudge someone's real reason for wanting to scale with AI (like in the story at the top) it would be a good idea set yourself up for success as best as possible.

There is this anonymous automation account called BowTiedAutomation who I follow on Twitter. Not really sure if he is an AI trainer or just an automation guy but I bought his workflow course a while ago and was pleased with it.

In his course, he narrows it down to five questions and I think these five questions give you the best possible chance at finding someone's true motivations for automation, and then it is off to the races from there.

Enjoy, and good luck.

See you in the next one,

Lucas

P.S. Join the AI Agency Academy for just $49 /month here and learn to automate, scale, and exit your agency.


Newsletter #7:
Title: Train Yourself To Be Resourceful
Body:
Hey,

It's Lucas from the AI Agency Academy here

This is one of the most important skills to develop when building automation systems.

The dictionary definition of resourceful is "having the ability to find quick and clever ways to overcome difficulties."

When people talk about "soft skills" to develop, this one rarely makes the list, yet is one of the most important skills to develop when learning AI automation. The key word here is develop. This is something that you can train yourself to do.

The easiest way to "become" a person who is resourceful with automation is to surround yourself and learn from people who are resourceful with AI tools. The main hurdle here is that you simply do not know the possibilities with automation, and in most cases, the only way to learn is to see it in action from someone further ahead of you.

Here is a good example of this.

Let's say that you want to build automated workflows for your agency but do not know where to start.

Start browsing through automation communities, save every workflow template you see with proven results
Get the workflow documentation, download it with tools like Notion or Airtable
Upload the template into N8N or Zapier and modify it to the first three steps (the trigger).
Edit your own business logic on top of theirs. Do this with 10-20 different workflows to create 10-20 automation foundations.
Connect these foundations to your existing tools and test which workflow performs best. Then, optimize that workflow with additional AI prompts and VA training protocols. You are now testing 10-20 effective automation patterns (they have proven results) in less than one hour.
It really is that easy. By taking their workflow foundations, you are bypassing likely months of testing and trial-and-error, and getting the majority of the automation benefit for yourself.

Join AI Agency Academy: If you own an agency or want to train virtual assistants and you want the systems, processes, and automation strategies that you need to scale using AI tools, consider joining AI Agency Academy.

Here are some results our members have achieved:

Automated 80% of client onboarding processes
Reduced manual work by 15+ hours per week using AI workflows
Trained VAs to manage complex automation systems
Built profitable micro-SaaS tools from internal processes
And many, many more automation wins.
See you in the next one,

Lucas

P.S. Join the AI Agency Academy for just $49 /month here and learn to automate, scale, and exit your agency.

REFERENCE DOCUMENT 1: Lucas Synnott & AI Agency Academy ‚Äì Project Knowledge Base

About Lucas Synnott
Name: Lucas Synnott
Location: Dublin, Ireland
Roles: Founder, Instructor, Automation Expert, Agency Consultant
Background: Business strategist and performance marketer with deep expertise in AI automation, funnel optimization, email marketing, and scaling agencies through systems. Lucas has built and exited multiple service businesses and now focuses on helping other agency owners do the same through automation-first education.

About AI Agency Academy
Company Overview:
AI Agency Academy is a training platform and community designed to help digital agency owners and their virtual assistants automate operations, increase profitability, and scale intelligently‚Äîwithout needing to be technical. Built on Skool, the academy delivers a structured curriculum, pre-built templates, and expert coaching to help members productize their internal systems and turn AI tools into revenue engines.

Core Services:

Primary: AI automation training for agency workflows

Secondary: Virtual assistant enablement and delegation systems

Additional: Lead generation, outbound sales, content creation, and fulfillment automations

Our Unique Approach:

Automation-First: Systems replace headcount.

VA-Centric: Train your assistant, not just yourself.

AI-Native: Everything is built using real tools‚Äîno theory, just working systems.

Productization-Driven: Internal tools become lead magnets, offers, or micro-SaaS.

Methodology:

Design offers and fulfillment around automation from day one

Use tools like N8N, Zapier, and Make.com to eliminate manual tasks

Train VAs to build, run, and improve operations using SOPs and AI tools

Productize backend systems into scalable assets

Use AI-generated content and outreach for audience growth and lead flow


REFERENCE DOCUMENT 2: Twitter Post Writing Masterclass ‚Äì Complete Guide
The Twitter/X Content Landscape in 2025
For You + Following feeds now weigh watch-time on video and read-time on text equally.

Short, idea-dense singles (‚â§ 280 chars) out-perform threads 3 √ó on impressions-per-word.

‚ÄúSee more‚Äù expansion rate and profile-clicks are the two hidden metrics driving reach.

Algorithm updates punish obvious bait; authenticity, numbers, and concise clarity win.

Content-Performance Benchmarks
Metric	High-Performer Target	Dataset Avg (top 5 % in CSV)
Impressions	‚â• 500 k	479 k
‚ù§Ô∏è / Impr.	‚â• 1.8 %	1.6 %
Profile Click-Thru	‚â• 0.7 %	0.65 %
Link CTR	‚â• 0.35 %	0.29 %

The 5-Step Tweet Framework
Step	Purpose	How-To
1. Find the Right Insight	- One fresh, specific observation that solves/clarifies a pain felt by agency owners & VAs.	Mine client DMs, sales calls, CSV tweet angles.
2. Develop One Clear Point	- One tweet = one payoff.	Angle it like a headline: journalist tone + benefit.
3. Micro-Structure	- H-I-C ‚Üí Hook (‚â§ 40 chars) ‚Üí Insight/Story (‚â§ 220 chars) ‚Üí CTA (‚â§ 20 chars)	White-space with ‚Äú\n‚Äù to create eye-rhythm.
4. Craft a Killer Hook	- Stop the scroll and set expectation.	Choose 1 of 12 proven hook types (next section).
5. Deliver the Promise	- Satisfy the hook, back it with a number, end with action.	Use 8th-grade language, active verbs, emojis ‚â§ 2.

12 Proven Hook Types 
Use these to open a tweet. Do not copy wording; mirror the energy, cadence, and length.

#	Hook Type	CSV Example (verbatim)
1	Unique Transformation	‚ÄúLife hack: Move from the city you grew up. You'll transform into an entirely new person.‚Äù
2	Failure Story	‚ÄúThe best way to fail in life: Never start because you're afraid of failing.‚Äù
3	Make People Feel Seen	‚ÄúYou're overcomplicating it, my friend.‚Äù
4	Strong Disagreement	‚ÄúFuck ‚ÄònEtwOrKinG.‚Äô Build your skill set.‚Äù
5	Opinion as Fact	‚ÄúThe smartest people I know are all writers.‚Äù
6	Rebellion Story	‚ÄúAbsolutely 0 clients have ever asked if I had a degree. You can just do stuff.‚Äù
7	Trigger FOMO	‚ÄúThere are 15-year-olds posting content and building businesses‚Ä¶‚Äù
8	Contrarian Take	‚ÄúDon't follow your passion. Find rich people's problems you'd be happy to solve.‚Äù
9	Set a Goal / Public Challenge	‚ÄúAdopt the mindset: If I don't post every day, my head explodes.‚Äù
10	Subject Masterclass	‚ÄúHow to find your niche in 69 seconds (watch the video): ‚Ä¶‚Äù
11	Golden Advice	‚ÄúDMs = Writing Email = Writing Content = Writing ‚Ä¶ Writing = $$$‚Äù
12	Leverage FOFO	‚ÄúThere's someone 3 √ó dumber than you making 2 √ó more. Because they took action on 1 book instead of reading 10 more.‚Äù

Formatting Best Practices for Singles
Whitespace rules: Max 2 sentences per line. Break before numbers or CTA.

Numbers > adjectives: ‚Äú58 % margin‚Äù beats ‚Äúhuge margin.‚Äù

Emojis: 0‚Äì2; only meaning-bearing (e.g., üöÄ, ‚ö°Ô∏è, üîó).

CTA ideas: ‚ÄúReply ‚ÄòAI‚Äô for the SOP,‚Äù ‚ÄúSave this,‚Äù ‚ÄúDM ‚ÄòSYSTEM‚Äô for details,‚Äù ‚ÄúJoin AI Agency Academy.‚Äù

Compliance: No thread-gate or ‚Äúlike/comment boosts,‚Äù keep it clean to dodge shadow throttling.

Quick-Reference Tweet Writing Checklist
‚ñ° Hook in first 40 characters.

‚ñ° One insight, one payoff.

‚ñ° Proof or micro-story (ideally with a stat).

‚ñ° Clear CTA tied to business goal.

‚ñ° Reads at 8th-grade level (Grammarly/FK ‚â§ 8).

‚ñ° Tone: confident operator, slightly edgy, action-biased.

‚ñ° No jargon unless defined in same tweet.

‚ñ° Character count ‚â§ 280 (incl. spaces & emoji).

Swipe-File: 8 High-Engagement Tweet Structures (CSV-Based Templates)
Life-hack punch

‚ÄúLife hack: <action>. <1-line payoff>.‚Äù

Stat + disbelief

‚Äú<Surprising stat> and nobody‚Äôs talking about it. Here‚Äôs why it matters for <audience>.‚Äù

Mini-rant

‚ÄúStop <common advice>. <Better alternative>. (Proof: <result stat>).‚Äù

One-sentence masterclass

‚Äú<Topic>: <3-step formula in one line with commas>.‚Äù

Call-out + fix

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre still <pain>, you‚Äôre leaking <cost>. Do <solution> instead.‚Äù

X > Y comparison

‚Äú<X> > <Y>. Here‚Äôs the ROI in 2 numbers: <#, #>.‚Äù

Fear-buster

‚ÄúAfraid of <obstacle>? Try <quick win>. Took me from <before stat> to <after stat>.‚Äù

Action guarantee

‚ÄúDo <simple daily habit> for 30 days and your <metric> will explode. I‚Äôll die on this hill.‚Äù

Use these shells + the Hook library to generate endless high-impact agency-focused tweets.

‚ñ° Clear CTA tied to business goal.

‚ñ° Reads at 8th-grade level (Grammarly/FK ‚â§ 8).

‚ñ° Tone: confident operator, slightly edgy, action-biased.

‚ñ° No jargon unless defined in same tweet.

‚ñ° Character count ‚â§ 280 (incl. spaces & emoji).
